revision.text:
[[File:Sun Yat Sen 1907.png|thumb|[[Sun Yat-sen]], one of the leaders of the [[Xinhai Revolution]] which overthrew the [[Qing dynasty]] in 1912. Photo taken in 1907]]
'''Anti-Qing sentiment''' ({{zh|t=反淸|p=fǎn Qing}}) refers to a sentiment principally held in [[China]] against the [[Manchu]] ruling during the [[Qing dynasty]] (1644–1912), which was accused by a number of opponents of being barbarian. The Qing was accused of destroying traditional [[Han Chinese|Han]] culture by forcing Han to wear their hair in a [[Queue (hairstyle)|queue]] in the [[Manchu people|Manchu]] style. It was blamed for suppressing Chinese science, [[Qing conquest theory|causing China to be transformed]] from the world's premiere power to a poor, backwards nation. The people of the [[Eight Banners]] lived off government pensions unlike the general Han civilian population.
The rallying slogan of anti-Qing activists was "Fǎn Qīng fù Míng" (simplified Chinese: 反淸复明; traditional Chinese: 反淸復明; literally: "Oppose Qing and restore [[Ming dynasty|Ming]]").
In the broadest sense, an anti-Qing activist was anyone who engaged in anti-Manchu [[direct action]]. This included people from many mainstream political movements and uprisings, such as [[Taiping Rebellion]], the [[Xinhai Revolution]], the [[Revolt of the Three Feudatories]], the [[Revive China Society]], the [[Tongmenghui]], the [[Panthay Rebellion]], [[White Lotus Rebellion]], and others.
==Ming loyalism in the early Qing== [[File:Zheng Chenggong.JPG|thumb|Statue of Zheng Chenggong on [[Gulangyu Island]] in [[Xiamen]], one of many in mainland China and Taiwan.]]
===Muslim Ming loyalists=== [[Hui people|Hui Muslim]] Ming loyalists under Mi Layin and Ding Guodong fought against the Qing to restore a Ming prince to the throne from 1646-1650. When the [[Qing dynasty]] invaded the [[Ming dynasty]] in 1644, Muslim Ming loyalists in Gansu led by Muslim leaders Milayin<ref>{{cite book|title=Beyond the Pass: Economy, Ethnicity, and Empire in Qing Central Asia, 1759-1864|first=James A.|last=Millward|volume=|edition=illustrated|year=1998|publisher=Stanford University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MC6sAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA298#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=298|isbn=0804729336|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> and Ding Guodong led a revolt in 1646 against the Qing during the [[Manchu conquest of China#The northwest|Milayin rebellion]] in order to drive the Qing out and restore the Ming Prince of Yanchang Zhu Shichuan to the throne as the emperor.<ref>{{cite book|title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China|first=Jonathan Neaman|last=Lipman|volume=|edition=|year=1998|publisher=University of Washington Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y8Nzux7z6KAC&pg=PA37#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=53|isbn=0295800550|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> The Muslim Ming loyalists were supported by Hami's Sultan Sa'id Baba and his son Prince Turumtay.<ref>{{cite book|title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China|first=Jonathan Neaman|last=Lipman|volume=|edition=|year=1998|publisher=University of Washington Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y8Nzux7z6KAC&pg=PA38&dq=milayin&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bcyOUKSzJdCI0QHu2oCIAQ&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=milayin&f=false|page=54|isbn=0295800550|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Beyond the Pass: Economy, Ethnicity, and Empire in Qing Central Asia, 1759-1864|first=James A.|last=Millward|volume=|edition=illustrated|year=1998|publisher=Stanford University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MC6sAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA171#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=171|isbn=0804729336|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Salar: A Study in Inner Asian Language Contact Processes, Part 1|first=Arienne M.|last=Dwyer|volume=|edition=illustrated|year=2007|publisher=Otto Harrassowitz Verlag|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ciShtCrJijIC&pg=PA8#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=8|isbn=3447040912|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> The Muslim Ming loyalists were joined by Tibetans and Han Chinese in the revolt.<ref>{{cite book|title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China|first=Jonathan Neaman|last=Lipman|volume=|edition=|year=1998|publisher=University of Washington Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y8Nzux7z6KAC&pg=PA39#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=55|isbn=0295800550|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> After fierce fighting, and negotiations, a peace agreement was agreed on in 1649, and Milayan and Ding nominally pledged allegiance to the Qing and were given ranks as members of the Qing military.<ref>{{cite book|title=GREAT ENTERPRISE|first=FREDERIC|last=WAKEMAN JR.|volume=|edition=|year=1986|publisher=University of California Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8nXLwSG2O8AC&pg=PA802#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=802|isbn=0520048040|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> When other Ming loyalists in southern China made a resurgence and the Qing were forced to withdraw their forces from Gansu to fight them, Milayan and Ding once again took up arms and rebelled against the Qing.<ref>{{cite book|title=GREAT ENTERPRISE|first=FREDERIC|last=WAKEMAN JR.|volume=|edition=|year=1986|publisher=University of California Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8nXLwSG2O8AC&pg=PA803&dq=milayin&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bcyOUKSzJdCI0QHu2oCIAQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=milayin&f=false|page=803|isbn=0520048040|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> The Muslim Ming loyalists were then crushed by the Qing with 100,000 of them, including Milayin, Ding Guodong, and Turumtay killed in battle.
The Confucian Hui Muslim scholar Ma Zhu (1640–1710) served with the southern Ming loyalists against the Qing.<ref>{{cite book|title=Charities in the Non-Western World: The Development and Regulation of Indigenous and Islamic Charities|editor1-first=Rajeswary Ampalavanar|editor1-last=Brown|editor2-first=Justin|editor2-last=Pierce|volume=|edition=|year=2013|publisher=Routledge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RVtKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA152#v=onepage&q&f=falsepage=152|isbn=1317938526|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref>
===Koxinga===
{{Main|Koxinga|Southern Ming|Kingdom of Tungning}}
The Ming loyalist general [[Zheng Chenggong]], better known by his title Koxinga, led a military movement to oppose the [[Qing dynasty]] from 1646 to 1662. He established the [[Kingdom of Tungning]] on the island of [[Taiwan]].
{{Clear}}
===Joseon===
{{Main|First Manchu invasion of Korea|Second Manchu invasion of Korea}}
[[Joseon]] Korea operated within the Ming [[Imperial Chinese tributary system|tributary system]] and had a strong alliance with the Ming during the [[Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–98)]]. This put Joseon in a dilemma when both [[Nurhaci]] and the Ming requested support. [[Gwanghaegun of Joseon|King Gwanghaegun]] tried to maintain neutrality, but most of his officials opposed him for not supporting the Ming, a longstanding ally.
In 1623 King Gwanghaegun was deposed and replaced by [[Injo of Joseon|King Injo]] (r. 1623–1649), who banished Gwanghaejun's supporters. Reverting his predecessor's foreign policy, the new king decided to support the Ming openly, but a rebellion led by military commander [[Yi Gwal]] erupted in 1624 and wrecked Joseon's military defenses in the north. Even after the rebellion had been suppressed, King Injo had to devote military forces to ensure the stability of the capital, leaving fewer soldiers to defend the northern borders.<ref name="Ebrey 349">{{harvnb|Ebrey|Walthall|Palais|2006|p=349}}</ref>
The Manchus invaded Korea twice, in 1627 and 1636, eventually forcing Joseon to sever its ties with the Ming and instead to become a tributary of the Manchus. However, there remained popular opposition to the Manchus in Korea. Joseon continued to use the Ming calendar rather than the Qing calendar, and Koreans continued to wear Ming-style clothing and hairstyles, rather than the Manchu [[Queue (hairstyle)|queue]]. After the fall of the Ming dynasty, Joseon Koreans saw themselves as continuing the traditions of [[Neo-Confucianism]].<ref name="Holcombe">{{harvnb|Holcombe|2011|p=176}}</ref>
==Anti-Qing rebellions==
===Mongol Rebellions=== The Mongols under Qing rule were divided into three primary groups- the Inner Mongols, the Outer [[Khalkha Mongols]], and the [[Oirats|Eastern Oirat Mongols]].
The Inner Mongolian [[Chahar Mongols|Chahar]] Khan [[Ligdan Khan]], a descendant of Genghis Khan, opposed and fought against the Qing until he died of smallpox in 1634. Thereafter, the Inner Mongols under his son [[Ejei Khan]] surrendered to the Qing in 1636 and was given the title of Prince (Qin Wang, 親王), and Inner Mongolian nobility became closely tied to the Qing royal family and intermarried with them extensively. Ejei Khan died in 1661 and was succeeded by his brother Abunai. After Abunai showed disaffection with Manchu Qing rule, he was placed under house arrested in 1669 in [[Shenyang]] and the [[Kangxi Emperor]] gave his title to his son Borni. Abunai then bid his time and then he and his brother Lubuzung revolted against the Qing in 1675 during the [[Revolt of the Three Feudatories]], with 3,000 Chahar Mongol followers joining in on the revolt. The Qing then crushed the rebels in a battle on April 20, 1675, killing Abunai and all his followers. Their title was abolished, all Chahar Mongol royal males were executed even if they were born to Manchu Qing princesses, and all Chahar Mongol royal females were sold into slavery except the Manchu Qing princesses. The Chahar Mongols were then put under the direct control of the Qing Emperor unlike the other Inner Mongol leagues which maintained their autonomy.
The Khalkha Mongols were more reluctant to come under Qing rule, only submitting to the [[Kangxi Emperor]] after they came under an invasion from the Oirat Mongol [[Dzungar Khanate]] under its leader [[Galdan]].
The Oirat [[Khoshut]] [[Upper Mongols]] in [[Qinghai]] rebelled against the Qing during the reign of the [[Yongzheng Emperor]] but were crushed and defeated.
[[File:Hotgoid Chingunjav Statue.JPG|thumb|Hotgoid Chingunjav Statue in Ulan-Bator]]
The Oirat Mongol [[Dzungar people|Dzungars]] in the [[Dzungar Khanate]] offered outright resistance and war against the Qing for decades until they Qing annihilated the Dzungars in the [[Dzungar genocide]]. Khalkha Mongol rebels under Prince [[Chingünjav]] had plotted with the Dzungar leader [[Amursana]] and led a rebellion against the Qing at the same time as the Dzungars. The Qing crushed the rebellion and executed Chingünjav and his entire family.
During the Xinhai Revolution, the Outer Khalkha Mongols staged an uprising against the Qing and expelled the Manchu [[Amban]]s.
===Taiping Rebellion=== {{Main|Taiping Rebellion|Taiping Heavenly Kingdom}}
[[File:Hong Xiuquan.jpg|thumb|A drawing of Hong Xiuquan as the "Heavenly King" (ca. 1860)]]
[[Hong Xiuquan]] (洪秀全, Hóng Xiùquán) was a [[Hakka people|Hakka]] Chinese who was the leader of the [[Taiping Rebellion]] (1850–1864) against the Qing dynasty. He proclaimed himself to be the [[Heavenly King]], established the [[Taiping Heavenly Kingdom]] and called [[Jesus Christ]] his brother.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}
====Genocide and extermination of Manchus==== Driven by their fierce hatred of Manchus, the Taiping launched a massive [[genocide]] against the Manchus to exterminate their entire race.
The genocide of Manchus was incredible, in every [[city]] they captured, the Taiping immediately rushed into the Manchu quarter of the city and killed all the Manchus. One Qing loyalist observed in the province of [[Hunan]] of the genocidal atrocities committed by the Taiping against the Manchus and wrote of the "pitiful Manchus", Manchu men, women and children who were exterminated by the Taiping with their swords. Once [[Hefei]] capitulated, the Taiping rushed into the Manchu quarter shouting "Kill the demons (Manchus)!" while engaging in their genocidal massacre of all the Manchus living there. [[Ningbo]]'s entire Manchu population was also annihilated by them.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wm4CuSvIYiEC&pg=PA139&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false| title=The Taiping Heavenly Kingdom: Rebellion and the Blasphemy of Empire | author=Thomas H. Reilly| publisher= University of Washington Press. Copyright. | page=139 | year=2011 | isbn=9780295801926}}</ref> The Taiping exterminated 40,000 Manchus in [[Nanjing]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Matthew White |author-link=Matthew White (historian) |title=Atrocities: The 100 Deadliest Episodes in Human History |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0-fQHlaIpR4C&pg=PA289 |year=2011 |publisher=W. W. Norton |page=289 |isbn=978-0-393-08192-3}}</ref> On 27 October 1853 they crossed the [[Yellow River]] in T'sang-chou and butchered 10,000 Manchus.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TCZpAAAAMAAJ | title=Warfare and Armed Conflicts: A Statistical Reference to Casualty and Other Figures | author=Micheal Clodfelter | page=256 | publisher=Mcfarland}}</ref>
===Red Turban Rebellion (1854–1856)=== {{Main|Red Turban Rebellion (1854–1856)}} When news reached their ears that the Taipings succeeded in conquered Nanjing, the anti-Manchu [[Cantonese people|Cantonese]] in the [[Pearl River Delta]] saw this as an opportunity and possibility of overthrowing the Manchus to restore Han rule over China, and began the [[Red Turban Rebellion (1854–1856)]]. These rebels were called 'Red Turbans' because of the red headscarves they wore.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6irEoGgDrm4C&pg=PA59#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Triad Societies: Western Accounts of the History, Sociology and Linguistics of Chinese Secret Societies, Volume 5 | page=59| author=Kingsley Bolton and Christopher Hutton | year=2010}}</ref>
The Red Turban Rebellion was initially quite successful as the rebels gained control of a considerable amount of territory. On July 1854, [[Foshan]] was occupied by the rebel.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yO8zPqi0_JYC&pg=PA630#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=The Middle Kingdom, Volume II, Part 2 | page=630| author=[[Samuel Wells Williams]]}}</ref> In a desperate attempt to the eradicate any facilities which may support the Red Turbans, the Qing forces burnt the northern suburbs in [[Guangzhou]] to prevent it from sheltering the rebels.
The rebellion was ultimately defeated in 1856, which was followed by the mass execution of suspected sympathisers and participants of the rebellion.
===Panthay Rebellion=== {{Main|Panthay Rebellion}}
The [[Panthay Rebellion]] leader [[Du Wenxiu]] declared his intention of overthrowing the Qing and driving the Manchus out of China. The rebellion started after massacres of Hui perpetrated by the Manchu authorities.<ref>{{cite book|title=East Asia: identities and change in the modern world, 1700-present|first=R. Keith|last=Schoppa|editor-first=|editor-last=|others=|volume=|edition=illustrated|year=2008|publisher=Pearson/Prentice Hall|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=jpPpU5O6F86eyATl94HAAg&id=2nEwAQAAIAAJ&dq=The+spark+that+ignited+the+rebellion+was+likely+the+Manchu+government-assisted+massacres+of+the+Hui.+Amid+this+unrest%2C+an+educated%2C+devout+Hui+named+Du+Wenxiu+established+the+kingdom+of+Panthay%2C+covering+about+half+of+Yunnan+province%2C+...&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=spark+massacres|page=58|isbn=0132431467|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> Du used anti-Manchu rhetoric in his rebellion against the Qing, calling for Han to join the Hui to overthrow the Manchu Qing after 200 years of their rule.<ref>{{cite book|title=China's Muslim Hui Community: Migration, Settlement and Sects|first=Michael|last=Dillon|volume=|edition=|year=1999|publisher=Curzon Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BwuSpFiOFfYC&pg=PA59&dq=du+wenxiu+manchu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vi2fUOLaGIun0AGctYCAAw&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=du%20wenxiu%20manchu&f=false|page=59|isbn=0700710264|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=China: A Modern History|first=Michael|last=Dillon|volume=|edition=reprint|year=2012|publisher=I.B.Tauris|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4aAk2rduE9wC&pg=PA90&dq=du+wenxiu+manchu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vi2fUOLaGIun0AGctYCAAw&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=90|isbn=1780763816|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> Du invited the fellow Hui Muslim leader Ma Rulong to join him in driving the Manchu Qing out and "recover China".<ref>{{cite book|title=The Chinese Sultanate: Islam, Ethnicity, and the Panthay Rebellion in Southwest China, 1856-1873|first=David G.|last=Atwill|volume=|edition=illustrated|year=2005|publisher=Stanford University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Da2M_viEclEC&pg=PA120&dq=du+wenxiu+manchu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vi2fUOLaGIun0AGctYCAAw&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=120|isbn=0804751595|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> For his war against Manchu "oppression", Du "became a Muslim hero", while Ma Rulong defected to the Qing.<ref>{{cite book|title=Asian Research Trends, Volumes 3-4|first=|last=|editor-first=|editor-last=|others=Contributor Yunesuko Higashi Ajia Bunka Kenkyū Sentā (Tokyo, Japan)|volume=|edition=|year=1993|publisher=Centre for East Asian Cultural Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=9z7XU-C8KKzKsQT02oLoDg&id=gCJuAAAAMAAJ&dq=While+Ma+soon+surrendered+to+the+Qing+dynasty%2C+Du+chose+to+fight%2C+and+as+a+result+became+a+Muslim+hero+for+waging+an+all-out+war+of+resistance+against+Manchu+oppression.+Du+Wenxiu+was+born+in+the+village+of+Jinji+in+Baoshan+ft+ill+prefecture&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=all-out+war|page=137|isbn=|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> On multiple occasions Kunming was attacked and sacked by Du Wenxiu's forces.<ref>{{cite book|title=China, Yunnan Province|first=Stephen|last=Mansfield|others=Compiled by Martin Walters|volume=|edition=illustrated|year=2007|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5mU5dN3mDeIC&pg=PA69&dq=du+wenxiu+manchu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vi2fUOLaGIun0AGctYCAAw&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=69|isbn=1841621692|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=China's Southwest|series=Regional Guide Series|first=|last=|others=Contributor Damian Harper|volume=|edition=illustrated|year=2007|publisher=Lonely Planet|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lgOGbpzDA5YC&pg=PA223&dq=du+wenxiu+manchu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-jefUJ_0C8rn0QGZw4GACA&ved=0CC8Q6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=du%20wenxiu%20manchu&f=false|page=223|isbn=1741041856|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> His capital was Dali.<ref>{{cite book|title=Asian Borderlands: The Transformation of Qing China's Yunnan Frontier|first=Charles Patterson|last=Giersch|editor-first=|editor-last=|others=|volume=|edition=illustrated|year=2006|publisher=Harvard University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-cWJq9JjoYMC&pg=PA217&dq=du+wenxiu+manchu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-jefUJ_0C8rn0QGZw4GACA&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=217|isbn=0674021711|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> The revolt ended in 1873.<ref>{{cite book|title=Traps Embraced Or Escaped: Elites in the Economic Development of Modern Japan and China|first=Carl|last=Mosk|editor-first=|editor-last=|others=|volume=|edition=|year=2011|publisher=World Scientific|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=05gMJ4QMV5wC&pg=PA62&dq=du+wenxiu+manchu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-jefUJ_0C8rn0QGZw4GACA&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=62|isbn=9814287520|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref> Du Wenxiu is regarded as a hero by the present day government of China.<ref>{{cite book|title=Comparative Civilizations Review, Issues 32-34|first=|last=|editor-first=|editor-last=|others=|volume=|edition=|year=1995|publisher=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iPLuAAAAMAAJ&q=Bai+tell+one+another+tales+about+a+Hui+(Muslim)+ethnic+minority+hero,+Du+Wenxiu,+defeated+by+a+Bai+hero,+Yang+Yuke,+but+these+are+not+allowed+to+be+published,+in+accordance+with+the+government+policy+of+the+%22unity+of+minorities.%22+Hui+stories+......+The+reason+for+this+favoritism+towards+Du+Wenxiu&dq=Bai+tell+one+another+tales+about+a+Hui+(Muslim)+ethnic+minority+hero,+Du+Wenxiu,+defeated+by+a+Bai+hero,+Yang+Yuke,+but+these+are+not+allowed+to+be+published,+in+accordance+with+the+government+policy+of+the+%22unity+of+minorities.%22+Hui+stories+......+The+reason+for+this+favoritism+towards+Du+Wenxiu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SJjpU7jbGKnlsASts4HQAQ&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA|page=36|isbn=|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}</ref>
===Tibetan rebellions===
Tibetan Buddhist Lamas rebelled against the Qing at Batang during the [[1905 Tibetan Rebellion]], assassinating the Manchu leader Fengquan, and also killing French Catholic missionaries and Tibetan converts to Catholicism.
==Late-Qing revolutionaries==
===Sun Yat-sen=== {{Main|Sun Yat-sen}} {{cquote|To restore our national independence, we must first [[Chinese nationalism|restore the Chinese nation]]. To restore the Chinese nation, we must drive the barbarian Manchus back to the [[Changbai Mountains]]. To get rid of the barbarians, we must first overthrow the present tyrannical, dictatorial, ugly, and corrupt Qing government. Fellow countrymen, a revolution is the only means to overthrow the Qing government!{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}}}
===Zou Rong=== {{Main|Zou Rong}} Born in Sichuan province in West China in 1885 to a merchant family, Zou (1885–1905) received a classical education but refused to sit for the civil service exams. He worked as a seal carver while pursuing classical studies. He gradually became interested in Western ideas and went to Japan to study in 1901, where he was exposed to radical revolutionary and anti-Manchu ideas.
Here are some quotations of Zou Rong:
"Sweep away millennia of despotism in all its forms, throw off millennia of slavishness, annihilate the five million and more of the furry and horned Manchu race, cleanse ourselves of 260 years of harsh and unremitting pain"<br /> "I do not begrudge repeating over and over again that internally we are slaves of the Manchus and suffering from their tyranny, externally we are being harassed by the Powers, and we are doubly enslaved."<br/> "Kill the emperor set up by the Manchus as a warning to the myriad generations that despotic government is not to be revived."<br/> "Settle the name of the country as the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]]."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chss.iup.edu/baumler/zourong.html |title=Zou Rong The Revolutionary Army |accessdate=2008-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926224557/http://www.chss.iup.edu/baumler/zourong.html |archivedate=2008-09-26 }}</ref>
== Overthrow of the Qing == {{Main|Xinhai Revolution}} [[File:Xinhai Revolution in Shanghai.jpg|right|thumb|450px|Nanjing Road during Xinhai Revolution, 1911]]
The [[Xinhai Revolution]] ({{zh |c = 辛亥革命 |p = Xīnhài gémìng}}) of 1911 was catalysed by the triumph of the [[Wuchang Uprising]], when the victorious '''Wuchang revolutionaries''' telegraphed the other provinces asking them to declare their independence, and 15 provinces in '''[[Southern China]]''' and '''[[Central China]]''' did so.<ref>Liu, Haiming. [2005] (2005). The Transnational History of a Chinese Family: Immigrant Letters, Family Business and Reverse Migration. New Brunswick, NJ: Rutgers University Press. {{ISBN|0-8135-3597-2}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8135-3597-5}}.</ref>
The revolution also saw widespread violence and massacres targeted against Manchu '''[[Eight Banners|Banner]]''' garrisons in cities throughout China.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=tgq1miGno-4C&pg=PA188#v=onepage&q&f=false Rhoads 2011], pp. 188-204.]</ref> These notorious massacres of Manchus include the mass-slaughter which happened in [[Wuhan]] where 10,000 Manchus were butchered and in '''[[Xi'an]]''' where another 20,000 Manchus were obliterated.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QiM2pF5PDR8C&pg=PA190 | title=Manchus and Han: Ethnic Relations and Political Power in Late Qing and Early Republican China, 1861–1928 | author=Edward J. M. Rhoads | page=190 | publisher=University of Washington | year=2000}}</ref>
Finally after more than two centuries, the Qing Dynasty was overthrown and China was established into a new [[republic]].
Texts which contained anti-Manchu content were banned by President [[Yuan Shikai]] during the [[Republic of China (1912–49)]].<ref name="Rhoads2000">{{cite book|author=Edward J. M. Rhoads|title=Manchus and Han: Ethnic Relations and Political Power in Late Qing and Early Republican China, 1861–1928|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QiM2pF5PDR8C&pg=PA266#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2000|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-98040-9|pages=266–}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Huang Zongxi]] * [[Gu Yanwu]] * [[Wang Fuzhi]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Qing dynasty topics}}
[[Category:Qing dynasty]] [[Category:Anti-national sentiment|Qing]] [[Category:Prejudices]] [[Category:Revolutionaries]] [[Category:Eight Banners]]

revision.text:
{{other uses|Asset (disambiguation)}}
In [[information security]], [[computer security]] and [[network security]], an '''asset''' is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information.<ref name=ISO13335>[http://www.iso.org/iso/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=39066 ISO/IEC 13335-1:2004 Information technology -- Security techniques -- Management of information and communications technology security -- Part 1: Concepts and models for information and communications technology security management]</ref><ref>[http://www.enisa.europa.eu/act/rm/cr/risk-management-inventory/glossary#G3 ENISA Glossary]</ref> Assets should be protected from illicit access, use, disclosure, alteration, destruction, and/or theft, resulting in loss to the organization.<ref name=FAIR>[http://www.riskmanagementinsight.com/media/docs/FAIR_introduction.pdf "An Introduction to Factor Analysis of Information Risk (FAIR)", Risk Management Insight LLC, November 2006] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141118061526/http://www.riskmanagementinsight.com/media/docs/FAIR_introduction.pdf |date=2014-11-18 }};</ref>
==The CIA Triad==
The goal of [[Information Security]] is to ensure the [[Confidentiality]], [[Integrity]] and [[Availability]] of assets from various [[Threat (computer)|threats]]. For example, a [[white hat (computer security)|hacker]] might [[Attack (computing)|attack]] a system in order to steal credit card numbers by [[exploit (computer security)|exploiting]] a [[Vulnerability (computing)|vulnerability]]. Information Security experts must assess the likely impact of an attack and employ appropriate [[countermeasure (computer)|countermeasures]].<ref name=RFC2828>IETF {{IETF RFC|2828}}</ref> In this case they might put up a [[firewall (computing)|firewall]] and [[encrypt]] their credit card numbers.
==Risk analysis==
When performing [[IT risk management##Risk assessment|risk analysis]] it is important to weigh how much to spend protecting each asset against the cost of losing the asset. It is also important to take into account the chance of each loss occurring. Intangible costs must also be factored in. If a hacker makes a copy of all a company's credit card numbers it does not cost them anything directly but the loss in fines and reputation can be enormous.
==See also== {{Portal|Computer security}} * [[Computer security]] * [[CIA triad]] * [[Countermeasure (computer)]] * [[Factor Analysis of Information Risk]] * [[ENISA]] * [[Exploit (computer security)]] * [[FISMA]] * [[IETF]] * [[Information security]] * [[Information Security Management System]] * [[Integrity]] * [[IT risk]] * [[NIST]] * [[Risk factor (computing)|Risk factor]] * [[Risk management]]
==References== <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110726055502/http://fismapedia.org/index.php?title=Term%3AAsset FISMApedia TERM]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Asset (Computing)}} [[Category:Data security]] [[Category:IT risk management]] [[Category:Reliability analysis]] [[Category:Security compliance]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]]

Commons | blank2_info_sec2 = Bishop Hill, Illinois | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Bishop Hill''' is a village in [[Henry County, Illinois|Henry County]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]], along the [[Edwards River (Illinois)|South Edwards River]]. The population was 128 at the 2010 census, up from 125 in 2000. It is the home of the [[Bishop Hill State Historic Site]], a park operated by the [[Illinois Historic Preservation Agency]].
==Geography==
Bishop Hill is located at {{coord|41|12|3|N|90|7|6|W|type:city}} (41.200711, -90.118327).<ref name="GR1">{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/geo/www/gazetteer/gazette.html|publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]|accessdate=2011-04-23|date=2011-02-12|title=US Gazetteer files: 2010, 2000, and 1990}}</ref>
According to the 2010 census, Bishop Hill has a total area of {{convert|0.53|sqmi|sqkm|2}}, all land.<ref name="census-g001">{{cite web |url=http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_SF1/G001/1600000US1706171 |title=G001 - Geographic Identifiers - 2010 Census Summary File 1 |accessdate=2015-08-02 |publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]}}</ref>
==History==
===Erik Jansson=== {{main|Eric Jansson}} The village was founded in 1846 by [[Sweden|Swedish]] immigrants affiliated with the [[Pietism|Pietist]] movement, led by [[Erik Jansson]]. Prior to founding the [[Bishop Hill Colony]], Jansson preached to his followers in [[Sweden]] about what he considered to be the abominations of the [[Lutheran Church]] and emphasized the doctrine that the faithful were without sin. As Jansson's ideas became more radical, he began to lose support from many of his sympathizers and was forced to leave Sweden in the midst of growing persecution. Jansson had previously sent Olof Olsson, a trusted follower, as an emissary to the [[United States]] to find a suitable location where the [[Janssonists]] could set up a [[utopian]] community centered on their religious beliefs. According to Jansson, this community would become the "New Jerusalem", and their beliefs would soon spread across the world. As a result, 1400 colonists emigrated from Sweden to their new home in western [[Illinois]].
The colony struggled early on after its founding. Many of the first 1000 colonists died from disease on the way to Bishop Hill (named for Eric Jansson's birthplace, Biskopskulla), while others became disillusioned and stayed in [[New York (state)|New York]]. The quarters in Bishop Hill were cold and crowded and food was scarce. After the first winter, life at the colony began to improve. In the next few years housing was upgraded from dugouts to brick living areas, and crops were planted on {{convert|700|acre|km2}} of land. By 1849, Bishop Hill had constructed a flour mill, two sawmills, a three-story frame church, and various other buildings. The Bishop Hill Colony was [[communistic]] in nature, as dictated by Jansson. Thus, everything was owned by everyone and no one had more possessions than another. Work in the colony was highly rigorous and regimented. It wasn't uncommon to see hundreds of people working together in the fields or large groups of laborers engaged in other tasks.
===After Jansson and today=== {{main|Bishop Hill Colony}} The Bishop Hill colony underwent a major upheaval in 1850 after the murder of Erik Jansson. Jansson was assassinated by a former colony member, John Root, who was upset with Jansson for interfering with his marriage to one of Jansson's cousins. After their leader's death, the people of Bishop Hill appointed a group of seven trustees to run the affairs of the colony. Among the trustees were Jonas Olsson and Olof Johnson, who would become the primary leaders of the colony as they had been two of Jansson's closest aides. Under these two men and the rest of the trustees, the colony continued to grow and flourish. The workforce was reorganized to become more efficient and more buildings were erected. However, despite Bishop Hill's success, in 1857 financial problems arose in the midst of accusations of mismanagement against Olof Johnson. Johnson had made several large investments, without colony approval, that had turned out to be disastrous. As Bishop Hill headed for financial ruin, colonists voted to end the communal system. In 1861 the formal [[dissolution (law)|dissolution]] of the colony was official, and many of its people would soon be forced to move away.
[[File:Colony Church Bishop Hill Colony.jpg|thumb|Colony Church built in 1848.]] The Janssonist emigrants were a significant group of men and women to move from [[Sweden]] to the United States. Letters home from Janssonists to their friends and family, telling of the fertile agricultural land in the interior of North America, stimulated substantial migration for several decades and contributed to the formation of the [[Swedish-American]] ethnic community of the American [[Midwest]].
Descendants of Erik Jansson still lived in the colony until December 20, 2004 when Erik's great-great grandson and Bishop Hill volunteer fireman Theodore Arthur Myhre Sr. died south of the Colony while on a fire service call. Other known descendents remain in Illinois.
Surviving buildings built by the Janssonists are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. Bishop Hill is interpreted as a living community of Swedish-American heritage. Due to state budget cuts the Bishop Hill State Historic Site was closed for nearly 5 months from December 1, 2008 to April 23, 2009. Today the Site is open Wednesday to Friday during normal business hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.galvanews.com/news/x303479165/BH-state-site-now-re-open |title=BH state site now re-open |publisher=Galva News |first=Doug |last=Boock |date=April 23, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711070556/http://www.galvanews.com/news/x303479165/BH-state-site-now-re-open |archivedate=July 11, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Demographics== {{US Census population |1880= 350 |1890= 330 |1900= 345 |1910= 289 |1920= 274 |1930= 208 |1940= 199 |1950= 202 |1960= 164 |1970= 191 |1980= 166 |1990= 131 |2000= 125 |2010= 128 |estyear=2016 |estimate=125 |estref=<ref name="USCensusEst2016">{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/popest/data/tables.2016.html|title=Population and Housing Unit Estimates|accessdate=June 9, 2017}}</ref> |footnote=U.S. Decennial Census<ref name="DecennialCensus">{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/prod/www/decennial.html|title=Census of Population and Housing|publisher=Census.gov|accessdate=June 4, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YSasqtfX?url=http://www.census.gov/prod/www/decennial.html|archivedate=May 12, 2015|df=}}</ref> }} As of the [[census]]<ref name="GR2">{{cite web |url=http://factfinder2.census.gov |publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]] |accessdate=2008-01-31 |title=American FactFinder |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911234518/http://factfinder2.census.gov/ |archivedate=2013-09-11 |df= }}</ref> of 2000, there were 125 people, 56 households, and 38 families residing in the village. The [[population density]] was 232.0 people per square mile (89.4/km²). There were 59 housing units at an average density of 109.5 per square mile (42.2/km²). The racial makeup of the village was 100.00% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]]. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 0.80% of the population. 26.9% were of [[swedish people|Swedish]], 15.1% [[united states|American]], 14.3% [[english people|English]], 14.3% [[germans|German]], 7.6% [[italians|Italian]] and 5.9% [[poles|Polish]] ancestry according to [[Census 2000]].
There were 56 households out of which 23.2% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 60.7% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 7.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.4% were non-families. 28.6% of all households were made up of individuals and 14.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.23 and the average family size was 2.69.
In the village, the population was spread out with 18.4% under the age of 18, 7.2% from 18 to 24, 16.0% from 25 to 44, 38.4% from 45 to 64, and 20.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 48 years. For every 100 females, there were 89.4 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 88.9 males.
The median income for a household in the village was $47,083, and the median income for a family was $50,000. Males had a median income of $38,214 versus $18,750 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the village was $26,145. None of the population and none of the families were below the [[poverty line]].
'''2010 Census''' According to the 2010 Census, the population was 128, all of which were White, none of whom were Hispanic or Latino (of any race)<ref>http://censusviewer.com/city/il/bishophill/2010</ref>
==Notable person== <!-- Note: · Only people who already have a Wikipedia article may appear here. This establishes notability. · The article must mention how they are associated with <city name>, whether born, raised, or residing. · The fact of their association should have a reliable source cited. · Alphabetical by last name please · All others will be deleted without further explanation -->
* [[Hick Cady]], catcher for the [[Boston Red Sox]] and [[Philadelphia Phillies]]
==References== <references />
== Further reading == * Mikkelsen, Michael A. "The Bishop Hill Colony: A Religious Communistic Settlement in Henry County, Illinois." ''Church and State Columbus And America''. Baltimore, MD: The Johns Hopkins Press, 1892. 11-80. * Wagner, Jon. "Eric Jannson and the Bishop Hill Colony." ''America's Communal Utopias''. Ed. Donald Pitzer. North Carolina: University of North Carolina Press, 1997. 297-318. * Hallström, Jan Erik "The Patriarch from Helsingland - Jonas Olson of Bishop Hill. Early Swedish emigration to America", 2017 ({{ISBN|978-91-639-2188-9}})
==External links== {{wikinews|Illinois budget cuts to close historic sites and parks}} *[http://www.outfitters.com/illinois/henry/bishop_hill.html Bishop Hill information] *[http://www.bishophill.com/ Bishop Hill] *[http://www.historichenrycounty.com/ Henry County Historical Society]
{{Henry County, Illinois}}

revision.comment: HTTP→HTTPS for Senate.gov, per [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/Bender the Bot 8|BRFA 8]], replaced: http://www.senate.gov/ → https://www.senate.gov/ (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{double image|right|Sherrod Brown official photo 2009.jpg|140|Ted Kaufman, official Senate photo portrait, 2009.jpg|140|Brown|Kaufman|Sen. Ted Kaufman|Sen. Sherrod Brown}} The '''Brown–Kaufman amendment''' (or the '''SAFE Banking Act''')<ref name="Play">{{cite news |title=Brown-Kaufman Amendment: The State Of Play |author=Simon Johnson |newspaper=The Huffington Post |date=May 6, 2011 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/simon-johnson/brown-kaufman-amendment-t_b_566024.html |accessdate=December 5, 2011}}</ref> was a failed 2010 amendment proposed in the [[United States Senate]] to be part of the [[Dodd–Frank bill]] by Democratic Senators [[Sherrod Brown]] (OH) and [[Ted Kaufman]] (DE). It sought to address the [[moral hazard]] of [[too big to fail]] by breaking up the largest banks with limits on the size of financial institutions.<ref name="Fed Lending">{{cite news |title=The Fed's Lending During the Crisis Revealed: Transcript |newspaper=On The Media |date=December 2, 2011 |url=http://www.onthemedia.org/2011/dec/02/feds-lending-during-crisis-revealed/transcript/ |accessdate=December 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513141107/http://www.onthemedia.org/2011/dec/02/feds-lending-during-crisis-revealed/transcript/ |archivedate=May 13, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Push">{{cite news |title=Senate Liberals Push for Strict Financial Rules |author=David M. Herszenhorn |newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 5, 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/06/business/economy/06dems.html}}</ref> ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' said the amendment was based on the idea that "too big to fail is too big to exist."<ref name="EB"/> ''[[The New York Times]]'' called it a liberal initiative with pure "populist appeal".<ref name="Push"/>
The proposal failed on the Senate floor by a vote of 61 to 33 on May 6, 2010.<ref name="Vote">{{citation |title=U.S. Senate Roll Call Vote #136, 111th Congress - 2nd Session |date=May 6, 2010 |url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=111&session=2&vote=00136 |accessdate=October 23, 2012}}</ref> Economist [[Simon Johnson (economist)|Simon Johnson]] emphasized that only a handful of Republicans voted for the bill and that the Obama administration opposed the amendment.<ref name="Really">{{cite news |title=Does the U.S. Really Have a Fiscal Crisis? |author=[[Simon Johnson (economist)|Simon Johnson]] |newspaper=The New York Times |date=February 24, 2011 |url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/24/does-the-u-s-really-have-a-fiscal-crisis/ |accessdate=December 5, 2011}}</ref> After the vote, ''[[The American Prospect]]'' said the 33 "Yea" votes represented a "fascinating coalition – liberals and conservatives, Democratic leadership and three Republican conservatives."<ref>{{cite news |title=On the Death of Brown-Kaufman |author=Tim Fernholz |newspaper=The American Prospect |date=May 7, 2010 |url=http://prospect.org/article/death-brown-kaufman |accessdate=December 5, 2010}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' said the amendment was strongly opposed by [[Wall Street]];<ref name="Push"/> supporters included ''The New York Times''' editorial page, the editorial board of ''The Christian Science Monitor'', and Simon Johnson.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Editorial Board|title=The Hard Work Ahead on Financial Reform|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/05/opinion/05wed1.html|website=The New York Times|date=4 May 2010}}</ref><ref name="EB">{{cite news |title=The weak spot in the financial reform bill |author=Editorial Board |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=April 27, 2010 |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Commentary/the-monitors-view/2010/0427/The-weak-spot-in-the-financial-reform-bill |accessdate=December 5, 2010 |page=23}}</ref><ref name="Play"/>
To ''The Christian Science Monitor'', former [[Federal Reserve]] chairman [[Alan Greenspan]] hinted at support for the idea behind the amendment with his statement that "If they’re too big to fail, they're too big."<ref name="EB"/> Related legislation was passed in the [[Bank Holding Company Act Amendments of 1970|Bank Holding Act of 1970]], which gave regulatory powers to the [[Federal Reserve]] to cap bank sizes, but it was weakly enforced.<ref name="EB"/> A previous (1994) law limited a bank's total deposits to less than 10% of the nation's total, but waivers were issued to [[JPMorgan Chase]], [[Wells Fargo]], and [[Bank of America]].<ref name="Scrutiny">{{cite news |title=Financial Debate Renews Scrutiny on Banks' Size |author=David M. Herzenhorn and Sewell Chan |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 21, 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/22/business/22fail.html}}</ref>
The amendment would have capped deposits and other liabilities<ref name="Push"/> and restricted bank assets to 10% of US [[GDP]]. At the time of the Senate vote, three banks, JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, and Bank of America, exceeded that proposed amount.<ref name="EB"/> Any one bank's non-deposit liabilities would have been capped at 2% of GDP and for non-bank financial firms, the amount would have been 3%.<ref name="Scrutiny"/>
==See also== *[[Volcker Rule]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=111&session=2&vote=00136 Senate vote]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Brown-Kaufman amendment}} [[Category:2010 in American politics]] [[Category:United States proposed federal legislation]] [[Category:United States federal legislation]] [[Category:Proposed laws of the United States]] {{econ-policy-stub}}

{{distinguish|Jimmy Carter Library and Museum}} {{tone|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox organization | name = The Carter Center | logo = [[Image:The Carter Center.jpg|250px]] | type = [[Non-profit organization|Not-for-profit]], [[non-governmental organization]]
([[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] [[Tax exemption|exemption status]]): [[501(c)(3)]] | tax_id = 58-1454716 | founded_date = {{start date and age|1982}} | founder = [[Jimmy Carter]]
[[Rosalynn Carter]] | location = One Copenhill
453 Freedom Parkway
[[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|GA]] 30307
[[United States|USA]] | origins = | key_people = [[Jimmy Carter]], co-founder
[[Rosalynn Carter]], co-founder
Ambassador (Ret.) [[Mary Ann Peters]] [[chief executive officer|CEO]]{{cite web|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/news/experts/mary_ann_peters.html|title=Ambassador Mary Ann Peters Biography|author=The Carter Center|publisher=}}
[[Jason Carter (politician)|Jason Carter]], [[Chairman|Chair, Board of Trustees]]
Jordan Ryan, Vice President, Peace Programs
[[Donald Hopkins]], Vice President, Health Programs
Phil Wise, Vice President, Operations{{Cite book | title = The Carter Center Annual Report 2008-09 | publisher = The Carter Center | year = 2010 | location = Atlanta | pages = 82 | url = http://www.cartercenter.org/resources/pdfs/news/annual_reports/annual-report-09.pdf }} | area_served = Global (75 countries since 1982){{Cite book | title = The Carter Center Annual Report 2008-09 | publisher = The Carter Center | year = 2010 | location = Atlanta | pages = 80–81 | url = http://www.cartercenter.org/resources/pdfs/news/annual_reports/annual-report-09.pdf }} | product = | focus = [[Human rights]], [[Conflict resolution]], [[Election monitoring]], [[Public health]], [[Eradication of infectious diseases]], [[Mental health]] | method = [[Popular education]], [[Information access|Access to information]], Aid distribution | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 175; field office staff in more than a dozen countries | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = "Waging Peace. Fighting Disease. Building Hope." | homepage = [http://www.cartercenter.org www.cartercenter.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = Partnered with [[Emory University]] }} The '''Carter Center''' is a [[non-governmental organization|nongovernmental]], [[non profit organization|not-for-profit]] organization founded in 1982 by former [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Jimmy Carter]]. He and his wife [[Rosalynn Carter]] partnered with [[Emory University]] just after his defeat in the [[United States presidential election, 1980|1980 U.S. Presidential elections]]. The center is located in a shared building adjacent to the [[Jimmy Carter Library and Museum]] on {{convert|37|acre|m2}} of parkland, on the site of the razed [[Neighborhoods of Atlanta|neighborhood]] of [[Copenhill]], two miles (3 km) from downtown [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. The library and museum are owned and operated by the [[National Archives and Records Administration|United States National Archives and Records Administration]], while the Center is governed by a Board of Trustees, consisting of business leaders, educators, former government officials, and [[philanthropy|philanthropists]]. The Carter Center's goal is to [[human rights defenders|advance human rights]] and alleviate human [[suffering]],{{cite web|url=http://www.georgiatrend.com/November-2012/The-Carter-Center-At-30-Years/|title=The Carter Center At 30 Years|publisher=GeorgiaTrend|accessdate=11 March 2013}} including helping improve the [[quality of life]] for people in more than 80 countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/index.html|title=The Carter Center – Waging Peace. Fighting Disease|work=The Carter Center}} The center has many projects including [[election monitoring]], supporting locally led [[state-building]] and democratic institution-building in various countries, mediating conflicts between warring states, and intervening with [[heads of states]] on behalf of victims of [[human rights]] abuses. It also leads disease eradication efforts, spearheading the campaign to eradicate [[Guinea worm disease]], as well as controlling and treating [[onchocerciasis]], [[trachoma]], [[lymphatic filariasis]], and [[malaria]] through awareness campaigns. In 2002, President Carter received the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] for his work “to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts, to advance democracy and human rights, and to promote economic and social development” through the Carter Center.[[Norwegian Nobel Committee]], 2002 Nobel Peace Prize announcement, [http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/peace/laureates/2002/press.html], October 11, 2002, accessed December 19, 2008. In 2007, he wrote an autobiography entitled ''Beyond the White House: Waging Peace, Fighting Disease, Building Hope'', which chronicles the first 25 years of The Carter Center. ==History== The Center was founded in 1982 and dedicated in 1986 with [[William Foege]] as its executive director.{{cite web |title=Timeline and History of The Carter Center [1981-1989] |url=http://www.cartercenter.org/about/history/chronology_1980.html |publisher=The Carter Center |accessdate=October 12, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091101123818/http://www.cartercenter.org/about/history/chronology_1980.html |archivedate=November 1, 2009 |df= }} In 1993, John Hardman was appointed executive director, and during the 1990s the Center received several multimillion-dollar donations to fight Guinea worm disease and to prevent blindness.{{cite web |title= Timeline and History of The Carter Center [1990-1999] |url= http://www.cartercenter.org/about/history/chronology_1990.html |publisher= The Carter Center |accessdate=October 12, 2009}} In 1994, the center launched an initiative called "Not Even One" to fight child death by firearm. On October 2, 1995, The Rosalynn Carter Georgia Mental Health Forum was held at The Carter Center. ==Governance== The Center is governed by a board of trustees, which oversees the organization’s assets and property and promotes its objectives and goals. A community advisory group – the Board of Councilors – includes public and private-sector leaders who support The Carter Center and its activities in their communities and organizations. Members attend quarterly presentations on the Center’s work. CEO (Ret.) Ambassador [[Mary Ann Peters]] oversees the Center’s day-to-day operations and staff of 175,{{Cite book | title = The Carter Center Annual Report 2008-09 | publisher = The Carter Center | year = 2010 | location = Atlanta | pages = 2 | url = http://www.cartercenter.org/resources/pdfs/news/annual_reports/annual-report-09.pdf }} which includes international experts{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} in the fields of peace and health. More than 100 student interns from universities around the world assist the staff each year.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} Center-based councils of eminent persons who offer guidance to or participate in Center activities include: the Council of Presidents and Prime Ministers of the Americas,{{cite web|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/peace/americas/council.html |title=A Peace Organization Making Peace Around The World - Carter Center |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151024000736/http://www.cartercenter.org/peace/americas/council.html |archivedate=2015-10-24 |df= }} the International Council for Conflict Resolution,{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} the International Task Force for Disease Eradication,{{cite web|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/health/itfde/current_members.html|title=International Disease Control and Prevention - Carter Center International Task Force for Disease Eradication|publisher=}} and the Mental Health Task Force.{{cite web|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/health/mental_health/taskforce.html|title=A Mental Health Organization Combatting the Stigma of Mental Illness - The Carter Center Mental Health Program|publisher=}} The Carter Center also collaborates with other public and private organizations. ==Peace programs== ===Observing elections=== The Carter Center performs [[election monitoring|election observation]], sending teams of observers to determine the legitimacy of 101 elections{{cite web|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/peace/democracy/observed.html|title=Carter Center list of elections observed|publisher=}} in 39 countries since 1989.The Carter Center, [http://www.cartercenter.org/peace/democracy/observed.html The Carter Center: Waging Peace Through Elections], accessed September 19, 2010. Carter Center observers analyze election laws, assess voter education and registration processes, and evaluate fairness in campaigns. The presence of impartial election observers deters interference or fraud in the voting process, and reassures voters that they can safely and secretly cast their ballots and that vote tabulation will be conducted without tampering. Teams typically include 30-100 highly qualified impartial observers – regional leaders, political scientists, regional specialists, and election observation professionals. The Carter Center sends observers only when invited by a country’s electoral authorities and welcomed by the major political parties. Observers do not interfere in the electoral process and do not represent the [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. government]].The Carter Center, [http://cartercenter.org/peace/democracy/center.html "How does The Carter Center choose which elections to monitor?"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016234658/http://cartercenter.org/peace/democracy/center.html |date=October 16, 2007 }}, accessed on December 19, 2008. The Center played a key role – with the [[United Nations|U.N.]] Electoral Assistance Division and the [[National Democratic Institute for International Affairs|National Democratic Institute]] – in building consensus on a common set of international principles for election observation.United Nations, [http://www.accessdemocracy.org/library/1923_declaration_102705.pdf "Declaration of Principles for International Election Observation and Code of Conduct for International Election Observers"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061129194810/http://www.accessdemocracy.org/library/1923_declaration_102705.pdf |date=November 29, 2006 }}, October 27, 2005, accessed on December 19, 2008. It is also leading the effort to develop effective methodologies for observing elections that employ new electronic voting technologies.Carter Center, [http://www.cartercenter.org/documents/elec_voting_oct11_07.pdf "Developing a Methodology for Observing Electronic Voting"], October 2007, accessed December 19, 2008. ===Strengthening democracy beyond elections=== The Carter Center supports the growth of [[democracy|democratic institutions]] to ensure that there is a respect for rule of law and [[human rights]], that government decisions are open and transparent, and that everyone can have adequate resources to compete fairly for public office. For example, the Center is supporting the efforts of civic leaders in [[Ethiopia]] to convene discussions about the most pressing and contentious political and social issues facing the country, and in the [[Palestinian Territories]], it maintains a small presence in [[Ramallah]] focused on the ongoing monitoring and analysis of critical issues of democratic development.Deborah Hakes, [http://cartercenter.org/news/pr/ramallah_office.html "Carter Center Field Office in Ramallah"], May 4, 2007, accessed on December 19, 2008. Democratic initiatives in [[Latin America]] include support for regional access-to-information programs, creation of an inter-American support network, and reform of political campaign financing. The Center-based Council of Presidents and Prime Ministers of the Americas plays an important role in accomplishing these objectives.Members of the Council of Presidents and Prime Ministers of the Americas, {{cite web |url=http://cartercenter.org/peace/americas/council.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080131172927/http://www.cartercenter.org/peace/americas/council.html |archivedate=2008-01-31 |df= }} The Carter Center also promotes the dissemination to emerging democracies and regional organizations of models, lessons, and best practices for democratic governance. The goal is to empower those in transitioning countries who are trying to build stronger democratic institutions and practices. ===Advancing human rights=== The Carter Center believes all people are entitled to basic [[human rights]]. These rights include political rights, such as peace, freedom, and self-governance, as well as the social rights of health care, food, shelter, and economic opportunity. The Center actively supports [[human rights defender]]s around the world. In partnership with [[Human Rights First]] and the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights]], the Center holds an annual human rights defenders policy forum hosted by [[Jimmy Carter|President Carter]] in [[Atlanta]].Carter Center Human Rights Defenders Initiative, [http://cartercenter.org/peace/human_rights/defenders/index.html], accessed December 19, 2008. President and [[Rosalynn Carter|Mrs. Carter]] have intervened with heads of state on behalf of [[human rights defender]]s and victims for more than 20 years. They often take their human rights concerns to heads of state in personal meetings and through letters. The Center and President Carter are strong supporters of the [[United Nations Human Rights Council|U.N. Human Rights Council]] and the [[International Criminal Court]]. Both oppose the [[death penalty]] and urge its abolition in the U.S. ===Mediating conflict=== Recalling President Carter’s success in the White House negotiating the long-lasting peace treaty between Israel and Egypt,{{cite web|url=http://www.jimmycarterlibrary.org/documents/campdavid|title=Index of /documents/campdavid|publisher=}} groups in conflict turn to The Carter Center to help them prevent and resolve conflict. Lacking any official authority, the Center has become a trusted broker for peace, serving as a channel for dialogue and negotiation. Recent examples include: * President Carter’s mission to [[North Korea]] in 1994, which paved the way for a U.S.-North Korea pact on nuclear issues.Jimmy Carter, [http://nytimes.com/2006/10/11/opinion/11carter.html?_r=1&oref=slogin "Solving the Korean Stalemate, One Step at a Time"], ''New York Times'', October 11, 2006, accessed December 19, 2008. * Assisting unofficial Israeli and Palestinian negotiators in designing a model agreement for peace – called the [[Geneva Accord (2003)|Geneva Accord]] – in 2002-03.BBC News, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3252530.stm "Moderates Launch Middle East Plan"], December 1, 2003, accessed December 19, 2008. * Negotiation of the [[Nairobi Agreement, 1999|Nairobi Agreement]] in 1999 between [[Sudan]] and [[Uganda]]Carter Center Press Release, [http://www.cartercenter.org/documents/nondatabase/nairobi%20agreement%201999.htm "Agreement Between Governments of Sudan and Uganda, Nairobi Agreement"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518010445/http://www.cartercenter.org/documents/nondatabase/nairobi%20agreement%201999.htm |date=2008-05-18 }}, December 8, 1999, accessed on December 19, 2008. * President Carter’s mission to [[Haiti]] in 1994 with Senator [[Sam Nunn]] and the then former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General [[Colin Powell]] to avert a U.S.-led multinational invasion and restore to power Haiti’s democratically elected president.Larry Rohter, [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/18/world/showdown-with-haiti-diplomacy-carter-in-haiti-pursues-peaceful-shift.html?pagewanted=all "SHOWDOWN WITH HAITI: DIPLOMACY; Carter, in Haiti, Pursues Peaceful Shift"], ''New York Times'', September 18, 1994, accessed on December 19, 2008. * President Carter’s historic trip to [[Cuba]] in 2002 to seek improved [[Cuba-United States relations|U.S.-Cuban relations]]BBC News, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/1988192.stm "Lift Cuba embargo, Carter tells U.S."], May 15, 2002, accessed on December 19, 2008. * Negotiation of a cease-fire in 1995 in [[Sudan]] to allow humanitarian groups treat Guinea worm disease and [[Onchocerciasis|river blindness]] and immunize children. * Holding summits in [[Egypt]] and [[Tunisia]] in 1995-96 to address violence in the [[African Great Lakes|Great Lakes region of Africa]]Carter Center Press Release, [http://cartercenter.org/news/documents/doc190.html "African Leaders Gather to Address Great Lakes Crisis"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719232025/http://www.cartercenter.org/news/documents/doc190.html |date=2008-07-19 }}, May 2, 1996, accessed on December 19, 2008. * An agreement on the restoration of low-level [[Colombia-Ecuador relations|diplomatic relations]] between [[Colombia]] and [[Ecuador]] under a deal brokered by the former president, as announced by the Carter Center on June 8, 2008.{{cite press release | title = Ecuador and Colombia Presidents Accept President Carter's Proposal to Renew Diplomatic Relations at the Level of Chargé d'Affaires, Immediately and Without Preconditions | publisher = The Carter Center | date = 2008-06-08 | url = http://www.cartercenter.net/news/pr/EcCol_060608.html | accessdate = 2008-12-19}}{{cite news | title = Colombia, Ecuador restore ties under deal with Carter | publisher = [[Thomson Reuters]] | date = 2008-06-08 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSN0628014920080606 | accessdate = 2008-12-19}} ===Assisting China village elections=== Since 1988, the [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese government]] has authorized direct [[Elections in the People's Republic of China|village elections]] to help maintain social and political order in the context of rapid economic reforms. At the invitation of China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, The Carter Center initiated a joint project in 1998 to standardize Chinese village election procedures and assist in training of election officials and elected [[National People’s Congress]] deputies. In 2011, the Carter Center was asked by the Chinese government to no longer observe elections and instead focus on advancing the US- China relationship. ==Health programs== The Center has prevented the suffering of millions of people around the world from illnesses often ignored by others. Health programs seek to provide people with the information and access to services they need to treat their illnesses and take steps to prevent future spread of [[disease]]. An emphasis is placed on building partnerships for change among international agencies, [[governments]], [[nongovernmental organizations]], and [[corporations]] and on working with ministries of health to strengthen or establish permanent [[health care]] delivery systems in the poorest nations. During his acceptance speech for the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 2002, Carter commented on what he felt is the greatest challenge the world faces: “Among all the possible choices, I decided that the most serious and universal problem is the growing chasm between the richest and poorest people on earth. Citizens of the ten wealthiest countries are now 75 times richer than those who live in the ten poorest ones, and the separation is increasing every year, not only between nations but also within them. The results of this disparity are root causes of most of the world’s unresolved problems, including starvation, illiteracy, environmental degradation, violent conflict and unnecessary illnesses that range from Guinea worm to HIV/AIDS. Tragically, in the industrialized world there is a terrible absence of understanding or concern about those who are enduring lives of despair and hopelessness. We have not yet made the commitment to share with others an appreciable part of our excessive wealth. This is a necessary and potentially rewarding burden that we should all be willing to assume."{{cite web|url=http://www.abilitymagazine.com/CarterCenter.html|title=''Ability Magazine: The Carter Center|accessdate=2012-04-06}} ===Disease eradication efforts=== The Carter Center began spearheading the campaign to eradicate [[Guinea worm disease]] worldwide in 1986. At the time, there were about 3.5 million annual cases of the disease in 20 countries in [[Africa]] and [[Asia]]. In 2016 there were 25 reported cases in three countries: [[South Sudan]], [[Chad]] and [[Ethiopia]].{{cite web |title=Guinea Worm Disease: Case Countdown |publisher=Carter Center |url=http://www.cartercenter.org/health/guinea_worm/mini_site/current.html}} Guinea worm disease is poised to be the first [[parasitic disease]] to be eradicated and the only disease to be eradicated without the use of [[vaccines]] or drugs. Within affected countries, the Center reinforces existing [[Eradication of infectious diseases|disease eradication]] programs by providing technical and financial assistance, as well as logistics and tools, such as donated filter cloth material, [[larvicide]], and medical kits.Donald G. McNeil, Jr., [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/26/international/africa/26worm.html "Dose of Tenacity Wears Down a Horrific Disease"], ''New York Times'', March 26, 2006, accessed February 2, 2014. The International Task Force for Disease Eradication has been based at The Carter Center since its formation in 1988. The group has reviewed more than 100 infectious diseases and identified six as potentially eradicable – [[dracunculiasis]], [[poliomyelitis]], [[mumps]], [[rubella]], [[lymphatic filariasis]], and [[cysticercosis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/health/itfde/index.html|title=Disease Control and Prevention - Carter Center International Task Force for Disease Eradication|publisher=}} ===Implementing disease control and treatment measures=== Since 1996, the Center has been a leader in the fight against [[onchocerciasis]], commonly known as river blindness – a [[parasitic disease]] transmitted by the bites of black flies. The Center has worked to stop the spread of the disease in 11 countries across [[Africa]] and the [[Americas]] by helping residents and local health workers institute and sustain drug treatment programs and health education activities. The international river blindness campaign seeks to eliminate the disease from the Western Hemisphere by 2015."Pan American Health Organization Passes Resolution to Interrupt Transmission of River Blindness in Latin America by 2012", [http://cartercenter.org/news/pr/river_blindness_latin_america.html], accessed on November 4, 2009. The Center has distributed more than 125 million doses of [[Ivermectin|Mectizan]] (ivermectin){{cite web |title=Eye of the Eagle, March 2010 (Vol. 11, No. 1)]|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/resources/pdfs/news/health_publications/eye_of_eagle/eoe-march2010-vol11no1.pdf |publisher= The Carter Center |accessdate=September 19, 2010}} – a drug donated by Merck & Co., Inc., that treats and prevents river blindness.{{cite web|url=http://www.mectizan.org|title=Home - Mectizan Donation Program|publisher=}} Center health workers also prevent transmission of [[trachoma]] – a bacterial infection that is the leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide. Trachoma is prevalent in places that lack the tools for basic hygiene, clean water, and adequate sanitation. The Center follows the [[World Health Organization]]’s four-pronged approach – called the SAFE strategy – to fight trachoma in six African countries.Paul M. Emerson, Matthew Burton, Anthony W. Solomon, Robin Bailey, & David Mabey, [http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/84/8/05-028696.pdf "The SAFE strategy for trachoma control: using operational research for policy, planning and implementation"], ''WHO'', August 2006, accessed December 19, 2008. The Trachoma Control Program is working to improve sanitation in those communities by building [[latrine]]s, providing corrective surgery, distributing [[antibiotic]]s, and educating communities on basic hygiene. {{As of|March 2010}}, The Carter Center has helped to build more than one million latrines in its effort to fight trachoma. The latrines contain and prevent human waste from serving as a breeding ground for the disease-carrying flies, thereby reducing one way the disease is spread.Mark Bixler, [http://www.cartercenter.org/news/documents/doc2100.html "Latrine program a hit: project deals with health, gender"], ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'', March 5, 2005, accessed December 19, 2008. [[Lymphatic filariasis]] and [[malaria]] are mosquito-borne diseases also targeted by The Carter Center. The Center has distributed four million long-lasting [[mosquito net|insecticidal bed nets]]. It has also established drug distribution systems in [[Nigeria]] to treat and stem the spread of lymphatic filariasis and [[schistosomiasis]].Carter Center, [http://www.cartercenter.org/news/features/h/malaria/bednets_ccn07spr.html "New Malaria Program Blankets Areas of Ethiopia with Bed Nets"], ''Carter Center News'', June 12, 2007, accessed December 19, 2008. ===Training public health workers=== The Carter Center believes in building networks of village-based health care workers to treat people for various diseases at the same time. Emphasis is on helping national and local governments establish programs that they can sustain into the future. Since 1997, the Center established with the [[Education in Ethiopia|Ethiopian ministries of health and education]] the Ethiopia Public Health Training Initiative to improve academic training for health care personnel in [[Ethiopia]] and increase access to [[Health in Ethiopia|health care]] in rural communities throughout the country. ===Strengthening agricultural production=== In partnership with the Sasakawa Africa Association, the Center has worked since 1986 in 15 [[sub-Saharan Africa]]n countries to teach 8-10 million small-scale farmers improved techniques that double or triple their crop yields.Sasakawa Africa Association, [http://www.saa-tokyo.org/english], accessed on December 19, 2008. The program promotes use of [[fertilizers]] and [[crop protection]] chemicals, [[Fertility (soil)|soil fertility]], and environmentally friendly agronomic methods of crop production. It also supports efforts to construct quality grain storage to sustain market prices for the farmer and ensure greater [[food security]], establish farmers' associations, and use quality food crops such as high-protein [[maize]]. ===Reducing stigma of mental illness=== [[Rosalynn Carter]] leads the Center’s efforts to fight stigma associated with [[mental disorder|mental illness]]. The Center works to improve U.S. public policies that can help prevent mental illnesses and increase equity in [[mental health|mental health care]], holding an annual symposium with national leaders in [[mental health]] and other fields. The Center also seeks to raise public awareness of mental health issues globally through the Rosalynn Carter Fellowships for Mental Health Journalism, which enable journalists to explore mental health issues. To date, more than 100 journalists have participated in the program."The Carter Center Awards 2009-2010 Rosalynn Carter Fellowships for Mental Health Journalism", [http://www.cartercenter.org/news/pr/mental-health-fellows-2009-2010.html], accessed on November 4, 2009. ==Accolades== [[Jimmy Carter|Mr. Carter]] received the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 2002 for his work through The Carter Center. The Carter Center received the inaugural Delta Prize for Global Understanding in 1999 – an award administered by the [[University of Georgia]].[http://www.uga.edu/news/deltaprize/1999Carter/carter.html "1999 Delta Prize Announcement: The Carter Center"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060807152731/http://www.uga.edu/news/deltaprize/1999Carter/carter.html |date=August 7, 2006 }}, April 27, 1999, accessed December 19, 2008. In 2006, the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]] presented The Carter Center with the Gates Award for Global Health.[http://www.gatesfoundation.org/GlobalHealth/relatedinfo/gatesaward/carter_center.htm "2006 Gates Award for Global Health: The Carter Center"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110055013/http://www.gatesfoundation.org/GlobalHealth/relatedinfo/gatesaward/carter_center.htm |date=January 10, 2008 }}, 2006, accessed December 19, 2008. The center was awarded [[Sheikh Hamdan bin Rashid Al Maktoum Award for Medical Sciences|Hamdan Award for Volunteers in Humanitarian Medical Services]] for 2013-14.{{cite web|url= http://www.hmaward.org.ae/archive.php?termid=60| title=Awards Centre|publisher= Sheikh Hamdan bin Rashid Al Maktoum Award for Medical Sciences|accessdate = 25 June 2015}} ===Annual auction=== The center holds an annual auction, which raised $1.6 million in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/news/local/carter-centers-annual-auction-brings-in-16-million/nWZnQ/|title=Carter Center’s annual auction brings in $1.6 million|publisher=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|accessdate=18 April 2013}} == Controversy == === Alleged funding-based bias === [[Alan Dershowitz]] asserts that the Center's focus "is away from significant Arab abuses and on [[Israel]]'s far less serious ones" and that this is influenced by the Center's receipt of donations from [[Arab]] sources.Alan M. Dershowitz, [http://www.standwithus.com/app/iNews/view_n.asp?ID=1177 Ex-President for Sale], [[StandWithUs]]. One of the initial contributors to the Center was [[Bank of Commerce and Credit International]] founder [[Agha Hasan Abedi]], who donated $500,000. Abedi and BCCI also donated $8 million to Carter's Global 2000 project.{{cite web|url=https://fas.org/irp/congress/1992_rpt/bcci/16ga.htm|title=16 - BCCI And Georgia Politicians|publisher=}} According to the Center, 3 percent of the total amount of contributions it has received since its founding in 1982 have been from donors in Mideast [[Arab]] nations.[http://cartercenter.org/resources/pdfs/peace/conflict_resolution/CC_MiddleEastFunding.pdf Background on the Carter Center's Middle East Funding], last accessed November 4, 2009 Of the donations from the Middle East, the Center states: "Seventy-eight percent of those funds have helped to support health programs in Africa, 14 percent have gone to the institution's endowment, 4 percent were for original construction of buildings at headquarters in Atlanta, Georgia, and 4 percent for projects to directly promote peace, such as specific election observations. === Venezuelan election === Some individuals have disputed the Center’s endorsement of the electoral process in the Venezuelan recall referendum of 2004.J. Michael Waller, {{cite web |url= http://www.centerforsecuritypolicy.org/modules/newsmanager/center%20publication%20pdfs/ocwhat_to_dovenezuela.pdf |title= "What to Do about Venezuela?" |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070630013004/http://www.centerforsecuritypolicy.org/modules/newsmanager/center%20publication%20pdfs/ocwhat_to_dovenezuela.pdf |archivedate= June 30, 2007 |df= }}  {{small|(75.0 [[Kibibyte|KiB]])}} Occasional Papers 6 [[Center for Security Policy]] May 2005, accessed December 19, 2008. Fox News' [[Doug Schoen]] told Michael Barone at ''U.S. News and World Report'', "Our internal sourcing tells us that there was fraud in the Venezuelan central commission. There are widespread reports of irregularities and evidence of fraud, many of them ably recorded by Mary Anastasia O'Grady in ''The Wall Street Journal'' last week. Carter is untroubled by any of this, and declares that Chavez won 'fair and square.'"[https://www.usnews.com/usnews/opinion/baroneweb/mb_040820.htm USNews.com: The National Interest: Exit polls in Venezuela (8/20/04)]{{cite web|url=http://www.opinionjournal.com/editorial/feature.html?id=110005586|title=Opinion|publisher=}} The Carter Center looked into the allegations and released a paper and statistical analysis reaffirming their original conclusions.Carter Center, 17 September 2004, [http://www.cartercenter.org/documents/1834.pdf Report on an Analysis of the Representativeness of the Second Audit Sample, and the Correlation between Petition Signers and the Yes Vote in the Aug. 15, 2004 Presidential Recall Referendum in Venezuela], accessed 20 February 2010 ==See also== * [[List of non-governmental organizations in the People's Republic of China]] * ''[[Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid]]'' ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Jimmy Carter Library and Museum}} * [https://www.cartercenter.org/ The Carter Center's website] * [https://www.jimmycarterlibrary.gov/ The Jimmy Carter Library and Museum's website] {{Jimmy Carter}} {{Rosalynn Carter}} {{Election Organizations}} {{Poncey-Highland}} [[Category:Buildings and monuments honoring American Presidents]] [[Category:Development charities based in the United States]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations]] [[Category:International human rights organizations]] [[Category:Jimmy Carter]] [[Category:Charities based in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Public health organizations]] [[Category:Rosalynn Carter]]
